comments.commentBody:
It is difficult to control for all maternal factors in a study such as this. Would like to see data from European C-sections, whether there is any difference in obesity rates in toddlers if data for this does exist.
Personally had 4 C-secs, and was committed to breastfeeding each baby. It is a decision to think about before delivery, whether planned C-secs (like mine were) or emergency C-secs.
All went well with breastfeeding, breastfed a year each baby. My 4 kids are all lean and healthy.
One help was also taking each baby to a cranial osteopath, a recommended route for all C-sec babies. As they do not go through the birth canal their heads do not finish that critical process of passing through the canal.
It helped to take them to an osteopath for lowering risk of ear infections and even helped my son latch on bettter.
Or as my grandfather would say, "More important is who owns the water."

To paraphrase Sartre: I'd rather not get involved in the struggle between optimism and pessimism. Reality is way beyond such simplistic notions of duality. Oh, but were it that simple. Like good and evil, heaven and hell, republican and democrats.

Please do not kill the monkeys like Americans kill deer. God given life must be put to proper use. They should be used for medical research.
That would not be a wasted life.

The problem is not carbs in general. Many vegetables have loads of calcium
in them. Whole grains are not bad for most people. You are correct in too many simple sugars causing trouble.

I've never heard that diabetes mellitus is the old term for type I and diabetes insipidus is the old term for type II, and that may be true, but currently, diabetes insipidus is actually a completely separate medical condition. Diabetes insipidus is a condition in which the kidneys are unable to conserve water, either due to a lack of ADH (central DI) or a problem with the kidneys' response to ADH (nephrogenic DI). Both type I and type II are now called diabetes mellitus. Just thought that might be a helpful clarification.

that's it. i've had it: we need a new name for type 1. i don't have the "diabetes" that people think of when they hear "diabetes." and sadly, "juvenile onset" now applies to both types.
ideas? autoimmune diabetes? maybe something more catchy? :-)

You may have made a particular study of this issue, but your comment here doesn't reflect that.

1. You say the energy from this plant is going to be exported - on what basis? India is a massively energy starved country- there are many Indian companies which will pay above the market rate for power- in any case, this is a public project and the government has absolutely no plans to allow power from this project to be exported. Billions of dollars worth of projects are stuck in India because of lack of avaiability of power.

2. There is no evidence that Russian nuclear technology is inherently unsafe. Statements like this show that whatever "research" you did doesn't amount to much. Indian scientists say that this project uses far more advanced technology than the Japanese plant which was developed decades back when nuclear technology was at its infancy. I don't know whether to believe them - but they have more credibility (for many Indians) than the activists.

3. It is a bit of a stretch to say that Indian business culture is inevitably corrupt . (and making this an argument against critically important infrastructure projects is just as absurd as it sounds). India produced many world class companies whose success have nothing to do with corruption in diverse fields such as IT, biotechnology and others. If we can trust the Indian governement with the safety of our nucelar weapons, missiles and fissile material - nuclear power doesn't seem more difficult than that.

Are you serious Mr. Cohen! What kind of study did you do about the KNPP? It is absolutely hogwash to state that the power from the plant would be exported, exported to where! Sri Lanka? France? Mars? Just tell me please! FYI, the power from the plant would be divided among the nearby states with Tamil Nadu (just so that you know KNPP is located in the state of Tamil Nadu in a country of India, hope this info helps your continuing studies in this matter!). Anyways, Tamil Nadu would get 50% of the power and the rest would be divided among Karnataka, Kerala and Andhra Pradesh states of India.
On what basis do you question the safety records of Rosatom? Is it because of Chernobyl accident? In that case should we state safety record of GE built nuclear plants are appalling too given that Fukushima was a GE built plan? Again for your info, Russia has been improving its nuclear power plant technologies since Chernobyl and the KNPP is the most upgraded version of Russian nuclear technology. FYI, Vietnam, China and Turkey have signed up with the same technology based plants.
Let us not get into business culture of countries. India and China are not the only country with corruption, it exists in western countries too including France and the US, it is just that western companies do it much more subtle manner and with finesse.
Please leave India alone. You ought to rather focus on the nuclear power plants in France where 70% of the power are nuclear generated.

Highlighting the issue is welcome, but the article gives the impression that the opposition to the plant is foolish and naive and that, by implicaiton, there are no strong arguments against the project.

I have made a particular study of the issue for a recent book, which talking to campaigners in India, and there are many good reasons to oppose this vainglorious scheme. Here are a few.

1. The electricity is not going to be available for use by the energy-starved peope of India (as the article implies). It is going to be exported - for private profit. There isn't even an electricity gird worthy of the name in the region.

2. The safety record of Rosatom is appalling, and falls far below Western standards. Russian nuclear technology is inherently unsafe and is bought only by developing economies looking for economies rather than safety.

3. India, like China, has a business culture which almost inevitably creates corrupt practices - such as the use of defetive materials in building projects. Add to this the social structures which, as the article implies, block real accountabilty and the new wave of nuclear reactors in seond and third world countries are truly a game of Russia Roulette.

Diet has to play a part in this equation. Marathon running has to play a positive part.
I remember when Jim Fixx died of heart disease while running. Everyone was so surprised. A vegan diet makes a heart attack nearly impossible if combined with aerobic exercise. 58 years old is very young to be dying of a heart attack while running in a marathon.

To be clear, the recommendation is "healthy men (of any age) should no longer be routinely screened for prostate cancer using the prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A., blood test. The reasons are that the harms (the most serious of which is unnecessary prostatectomy leaving healthy people impotent or incontinent, or both)

I am a physician (not in any high risk group for prostate cancer) who first had an elevated PSA shortly after testing became a standard of care, in the early 1990s. After months of costly investigations (fortunately not including a biopsy or prostatectomy) my physician determined that the abnormal result was a false positive, and the test returned to normal. For the last 10 years I have had to request - over and over with every physician I have seen - to not order the PSA test. They seem to accept my request only reluctantly.
It is a sad commentary on our health care system that physicians are so slow to accept recommendations that allow them to do less, decrease suffering, and save the heath care system and patients and society money .

Love all these comments...makes me hungry!
Collard Greens are power food! Made the right way, as in some of these recipes, even kids will wolf it down! I know from experience. Serve kids plain boring veggies and force them to eat them will not help in the long run. Adding a special touch goes a LONG way. Bon Appetit!
I'd like to know as well. Waiting for somebody else to change the pressure seems unlikely, especially when you often fly not in the US.

Suleika
I am going in for my bone marrow transplant this weekend after being in and out of the hospital since February when I too was diagnosed with AML. I am a 41 year old mother of three who teaches yoga and fitness and was shocked and devastated at the diagnosis as I am sure you were too. I have really loved following your journey and being able to relate to someone going through the same experience. I am thrilled to see that you are doing well and are out of the hospital. I wish you all the best.
I prepared the lasagna recipe using fresh collards from my garden and got rave reviews. I made my own tomato sauce before assemblying the dish. It was easy and excellent. Thank you Martha.
How unhappy your world must feel, if you take everything so harshly- step back and try and imagine enjoying life alittle-

A change in attitude isn't all it takes to be happy, but it's a crucial part of the equation and a great place to start... and it sounds like you need to start somewhere.  You really can be happy.  But you'll never get there if you don't even believe happiness is attainable.

Margaret, I have been both chronically pessimistic and sporadically optimistic in my life. I have also scrubbed my share of floors. I can say without hesitation, I fare better - financially, emotionally, in my relationship to the larger world - during my more positive phases.

It's not a cure-all or a quick fix. Nor does one need to become a "happy idiot" and deny all the hardship in the world. But focusing on the positive always makes a difference for the better.

And what, pray tell, is offensive about advising someone who scrubs floors to take a moment and admire their work. I've done it many, many times. There is honor and dignity in all honest work, no matter how humble. Suggesting there's not is, in my view, far more offensive.

It made me queazy too. And the comments even more so. Do you think people who are pessimistic are doing so to be popular or chic? For heavens sake, no! I would rather be an optimist, but thus far in my life I have simply found more reason to be pessimistic. Quite often, the glass is broken and leaking and I'm the one that has to fix it.

I get so tired of sanctimonious health "experts" telling me that I all it takes to be happy is a change in attitude. That's really condescending and not realistic for the majority of people's painful and difficult lives. And it's usually the lucky ones that are telling you this.

And yes, the worst line was about someone who is washing floors to stand back and admire their work. Yeah, right. How offensive.
8000' has been the typical cabin altitude in airliners for many years.

The last several times I flew, I brought along two different hand-held GPS devices, which if held next to a window can display location and provide some entertainment in aircraft not equipped to display flight data.  The devices also have a barometric altimeter which gives a fairly accurate elevation, although not precise.  On those several flights, all on Continental, the altimeter gave readings of about 8200 feet elevation, surprising me, as I had thought passenger aircraft were typically pressurized to a cabin "altitude" of between five and six thousand feet.  I think 8000+ feet cabin altitude is excessive and can cause symptoms of mountain sickness.  I would not want an elderly relative exposed to such elevations for long periods.  Has this issue been evaluated by independent medical authorities?  Are the airlines chintzing on pressurization to save money at the expense of passengers?
This is not only barely literate, it's irresponsible for the Times to let this slip past the moderator.
This is gibberish.

Are these people idiots or what? We have stealth pathogens infecting the masses of Autism at the rate of 1 in 29 now, ALL the other SYNDROMES caused by the same thing, and all you people do is worry about making money off a flu vaccine that does not work in depressed immune system and since the stealth pathogens like Borrelia are proven to be shareing at least 40% of its genes with WHATEVER it wants, you want to let the ID's perpetuate a swindle flu by adding even more infectious antigens to the mix. Not to mention pubmed is proving all organisms can share their genes now thanks to criminals who did not care what caused ALL the Syndromes only that they could make money treating the symptoms....STOP THE INSANITY AND TREAT THE SICK...ALL OF THEM....
http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=yOno_2m_8LY
The REAL AIDS/MadCow and why stupid failed to give us tests that work. Because they do NOT exhibit antibodies once they share their genes.
Hey John - your maths is fine, you just read it wrong - 28 deaths from 2000 to 2009, not IN 2009.
gas monkey? I hope youe never need real surgery or are very tough!

Gas Monkey? Go for it. After my wife suffered 3 hours of conscious paralysis (attorney said it was not worth suing over), I've viewed anesthesiologists as not much more than fakes who sit in the position of docs who don't want to be bothered by this low paying, low value service.

And then you find, through the NYT no less, that they had to take "lessons" and "establish standards" to keep their peers from killing their patients because --- get his -- they put the "gas" down the wrong hole (into the stomach, rather than the lungs). Wow, my auto mechanic can do a better job than that. And while expensive, he's a lot cheaper than Gas Monkeys.

I have been a family doc for 23 years. Kudos to the NYT for this article. The costs of colonoscopy and much else in medicine are simply outrageous. Keep the heat turned up.
On a personal note, I got scoped 2 years ago with conscious sedation with no gas monkey in attendance. It was fine.

My wife left her phone in a cab.  Of course, no receipt.  The woman who answered the phone at the TLC had no desire to track the ride by time and location and made that clear despite 3-1-1's insistance that they could do it.  The phone didn't show up at the lost and found police precincts.  I'm sure it was wiped and sold within 3 hours.

Not sure to who your comment is directed; nevertheless, no, it is not evil to want money.

But having money is not a license to run ripshod over those who don't. And you'd have to search far and wide to fulfill the myth that the anger expressed by the middle class and poor is a mere socialist rallying cry.

The fact is that corporations have found greener pastures overseas, yet continue to drain taxpayers for every bad decision corporations make, all under the guise that taxes and regulations are to blame for their every problem, when, in fact, corporate taxes are at their lowest levels in six decades, and the government has actually shrunk under President Obama.

Think about it: an educated and healthy person is a threat to the market as a potential competitor. The GOP thus expressly legislates market forces to favor those who are already in the market. They are the largest donors to the GOP, after all.

It's interesting that you don't seem to care much about the dependency corporations have on the public trough, but god forbid that an individual files a claim for food stamps or for unemployment insurance (for which he or she has already paid via wage deductions). Frank and Linda Public are scapegoated as the scourge of our times. To what end?

As for your comments about socialism, do you even know what that is? Seems to me that if you did, you would have written an entirely different comment.
5:30 - I agree about the technical aspect of the npuzzle.  It was annoying.  I just focused on Dick Clark.
Well done, Ross. Well done.

I'm sure you believed your comment when you wrote it but it has no basis in fact. It is illegal for physicians to split fees. Every state prohibits the practice for the very reason you offered.  Less than 25% of physicians belong to the AMA and most of them are in general practice. Perhaps the patients could have asked if the anesthesiologist were  "in-network".
gas monkey? I hope youe never need real surgery or are very tough!
